You know, I never thought I’d see the day. Raised in a BCI household, compliance was the air we breathed. But after the network blackout, the office became a real community.
No one’s BCI records worked. We shared lunches in the newsroom, skipped badge scans—just paper lists, like the old days.

People openly supported each other, high score or low. The official hierarchy meant nothing. Even my most loyal editor asked for help getting erased colleagues access to footage—off the record, of course.
The management couldn’t keep up. I watched longtime rule-followers spark up a mutual aid group, right across from the surveillance node. It gave me chills.
